choices.text: Acute and transient psychotic disorder

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with no significant past medical history is admitted to the hospital following a hip fracture surgery. On the second day after surgery, his family reports that he has become increasingly fearful and disoriented. He appears to be fixated on the curtains in the room and insists that he sees "strange creatures" climbing on them. He also has fluctuating levels of consciousness and is agitated at times. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

Option A.

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with delirium, which is characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, disturbances of consciousness, and perceptual disturbances, such as visual hallucinations (seeing strange creatures on the curtains). Delirium is common in hospitalized patients, particularly after surgery, and can be precipitated by various factors, such as medication side effects, metabolic disturbances, or pain.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. Dementia is a chronic and progressive neurodegenerative disorder that typically presents with cognitive decline and memory impairment, rather than acute onset confusion and hallucinations.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia can present with hallucinations and delusions. However, the acute onset of symptoms in the context of hip surgery and presence of disturbances of consciousness makes schizophrenia unlikely in this case.

 

Option D. Acute and transient psychotic disorder is characterized by sudden onset psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions, but the patient's presentation in the context of hip surgery and fluctuating levels of consciousness is more suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset of confusion, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and disturbances in attention and cognition. It is common in hospitalized patients, especially after surgery, and is distinguished by its reversible nature and the need for immediate medical attention to identify and treat the underlying cause.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 227.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension is admitted to the hospital for acute cholecystitis. On the second day of her hospital stay, she becomes increasingly confused, with periods of agitation and drowsiness. She is also experiencing perceptual disturbances and has difficulty focusing her attention. Which of the following symptoms is NOT typically associated with delirium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gradual cognitive decline

 

Option C.

 

Gradual cognitive decline is not typically associated with delirium. Instead, it is more characteristic of dementia. Delirium is an acute, fluctuating change in mental status characterized by confusion, altered level of consciousness, disorientation, and perceptual disturbances, including hallucinations. It often has a sudden onset, and its severity can fluctuate throughout the day.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Fluctuating levels of consciousness is a hallmark feature of delirium, with patients experiencing periods of agitation and drowsiness or hyperalertness and lethargy.

 

Option B. Disorientation, including to time, place, and person, is common in delirium and contributes to the confusion experienced by the patient.

 

Option D. Visual hallucinations are often present in delirium and can contribute to the distress and confusion experienced by the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is distinguished from dementia by its acute onset and fluctuating course.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital due to acute confusion and agitation. He is experiencing hallucinations, which are contributing to his agitation. Which of the following types of hallucinations is least likely to be associated with delirium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Olfactory hallucinations

 

Option D.

 

Delirium is a neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and perceptual disturbances. Hallucinations are a common feature of delirium, but certain types of hallucinations are more prevalent than others.

 

Olfactory hallucinations are the least likely type of hallucination to be associated with delirium. They are more commonly seen in other neuropsychiatric conditions, such as temporal lobe epilepsy or certain types of dementia. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Visual hallucinations are the most common type of hallucinations in delirium. They are often complex and may involve seeing objects, people, or animals that are not present.

 

Option B. Auditory hallucinations can also occur in delirium, but they are less common than visual hallucinations.

 

Option C. Tactile hallucinations are less common than visual and auditory hallucinations in delirium but can still occur. Patients may report sensations of something crawling on their skin or other abnormal sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual and auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with delirium than olfactory hallucinations. Delirium, particularly in elderly patients or those with underlying medical conditions, often presents with visual hallucinations, which can significantly contribute to the patient's confusion and agitation.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 227.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of Parkinson's disease is admitted to the hospital for a scheduled hip replacement surgery. Postoperatively, he develops acute confusion, agitation, and disorientation. The medical team suspects delirium as the cause of his symptoms. Which neurotransmitter imbalance is most likely involved in the development of delirium in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylcholine

 

Option C. 

 

Delirium is a neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and perceptual disturbances. Several neurotransmitters are thought to be involved in the pathophysiology of delirium, but the cholinergic system plays a central role.

 

Acetylcholine (C) is the primary neurotransmitter involved in delirium. Decreased acetylcholine levels in the brain are associated with the development of delirium, and conditions or medications that reduce cholinergic activity can increase the risk of delirium. 

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Dopamine is involved in various neuropsychiatric disorders, including Parkinson's disease and schizophrenia. However, it is not the primary neurotransmitter implicated in delirium.

 

Option B. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation and can contribute to neuropsychiatric disorders, such as depression and anxiety. While it may play a role in the development of delirium, it is not the primary neurotransmitter involved.

 

Option D. Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that plays a role in various neuropsychiatric disorders, including anxiety and epilepsy. However, it is not the primary neurotransmitter involved in delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is associated with cholinergic deficiency, primarily involving the Ascending Reticular Activating System.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 227.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis is admitted to the hospital for worsening confusion, agitation, and disorientation. The medical team suspects medication-induced delirium. Which class of medications is most likely to cause delirium in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anticholinergic medications

 

Option C.

 

Delirium is a neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and perceptual disturbances. Several factors can contribute to the development of delirium, including medications.

 

Anticholinergic medications (C) are the most likely class of medications to cause delirium, particularly in older adults. These drugs block the action of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in cognitive function and memory. Examples of anticholinergic medications include some antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, and antipsychotics. In older patients, even medications with mild anticholinergic effects can increase the risk of delirium.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Beta-blockers are used to treat hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias. While they can cause central nervous system side effects, they are not the primary class of medications associated with delirium.

 

Option B. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are used to treat pain and inflammation. While they can cause gastrointestinal, renal, and cardiovascular side effects, they are not the primary class of medications associated with delirium.

 

Option D. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are used to treat hypertension and heart failure. While they can cause side effects like cough, hyperkalemia, and renal dysfunction, they are not the primary class of medications associated with delirium.

 

Educational objective: 

 

 

Ref:  Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 232.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. The nursing staff reports that the patient is having episodes of confusion, agitation, and disorientation. The medical team wants to assess the patient for delirium. Which of the following screening tools is commonly used to identify delirium in hospitalized patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Confusion Assessment Method (CAM)

 

Option A.

 

Delirium is a neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by acute onset confusion, disorientation, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and perceptual disturbances. Early identification and management of delirium are crucial to improving patient outcomes.

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a widely used screening tool for identifying delirium in hospitalized patients. It is a brief, standardized instrument that assesses four features: acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a cognitive screening tool that assesses various aspects of cognitive function, including orientation, memory, attention, and language. While it may be useful in evaluating the severity of cognitive impairment, it is not specifically designed to diagnose delirium.

 

Option C. The Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) is a clinician-administered questionnaire used to assess the severity of depressive symptoms in patients. It is not used to screen for delirium.

 

Option D. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is a brief cognitive screening tool that evaluates multiple cognitive domains, including memory, attention, language, and executive function. While it may be useful in detecting mild cognitive impairment and early dementia, it is not specifically designed to diagnose delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 229.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with her daughter. The daughter reports that over the past year, her mother has been increasingly forgetful, losing items, and repeating questions. The patient has also been having difficulty managing her finances. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alzheimer's disease

 

Option A.

 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly population, accounting for 60-80% of cases. It is characterized by a progressive decline in cognitive function, memory loss, and difficulty with daily activities. Risk factors include advanced age, family history, and comorbidities such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus, as seen in this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia typically presents with changes in personality and behavior, rather than memory loss, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia is often associated with a history of cerebrovascular accidents or cardiovascular risk factors. However, the gradual onset of memory loss and cognitive decline in this patient is more consistent with Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia usually presents with fluctuating cognitive impairment, visual hallucinations, and Parkinsonian features. The clinical presentation in this case is more suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of progressive memory impairment, particularly in short-term memory, and difficulty with complex tasks such as managing finances in an elderly patient is most suggestive of Alzheimer's disease, the most common cause of dementia. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with his wife, who reports that he has been experiencing progressive memory loss, confusion, and spatial disorientation over the past six months. His symptoms have become severe enough to interfere with his daily activities. A brain MRI reveals atrophy of the medial temporal lobes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alzheimer's disease

 

Option A. 

 

Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by memory loss, confusion, and difficulty with daily activities. It is the most common cause of dementia in older adults. The MRI finding of medial temporal lobe atrophy is consistent with Alzheimer's disease, as in alzheimer's disease typically the atrophy begins in medial temporal lobes.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. Vascular dementia typically presents with a stepwise decline in cognitive function, often related to a history of cerebrovascular accidents or cardiovascular risk factors. The clinical presentation and MRI findings in this case are more suggestive of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C. Frontotemporal dementia usually presents with changes in personality & behavior, rather than memory loss and spatial disorientation, as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia is characterized by fluctuating cognitive impairment, visual hallucinations, and Parkinsonian features. The clinical presentation and MRI findings in this case are more consistent with Alzheimer's disease. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progressive memory loss, confusion, and spatial disorientation in an elderly patient, coupled with MRI findings of medial temporal lobe atrophy, strongly suggest Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the gradual onset and progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive functions, with medial temporal lobe atrophy being a common neuroimaging finding.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a one-year history of progressive memory loss, difficulty finding words, and difficulty completing daily tasks. Her family history reveals her mother had a similar condition in her late sixties. The patient is diagnosed with mild Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Donepezil

 

Option B. 

 

Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is commonly used to treat the symptoms of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. By inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, donepezil helps improve cognitive function and slow the progression of the disease. As the patient is experiencing mild Alzheimer's disease, donepezil is the most appropriate initial treatment.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Memantine is an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist that is used to treat moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It is not the first-line treatment for mild Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C. Risperidone and D. Haloperidol are antipsychotic medications that might be used to manage behavioral symptoms such as agitation, aggression, or psychosis in Alzheimer's disease patients. However, they are not the first-line treatment for the cognitive symptoms associated with mild Alzheimer's disease

 

Educational objective:

 

Donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is a common initial treatment for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. It works by increasing acetylcholine levels in the brain, which can help improve cognitive function in patients with Alzheimer's disease. Other cholinesterase inhibitors include rivastigmine and galantamine. Memantine is used in moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease and can be combined with cholinesterase inhibitors in some cases. Antipsychotics like risperidone and haloperidol are not first-line treatments for Alzheimer's disease and are used to manage behavioral symptoms, not cognitive decline.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text: All of the following are types of cortical dementias, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's disease

 

Option D. 

 

Huntington's disease is a type of subcortical dementia, characterized by movement disorders, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms due to degeneration primarily in the basal ganglia and associated brain structures. Subcortical dementias typically involve areas of the brain below the cortex and are associated with changes in the speed of cognitive processes, attention, and executive function rather than the memory and language deficits more characteristic of cortical dementias.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease and B. Frontotemporal dementia are examples of cortical dementias. In cortical dementias, the damage is primarily in the brain's cortical areas, leading to symptoms such as aphasia (language difficulties), agnosia (difficulty recognizing objects), and memory loss.

 

Option C. Lewy body dementia can present with features of both cortical and subcortical dementia, due to the widespread distribution of Lewy bodies in both cortical and subcortical structures. However, it is often grouped with cortical dementias because of its significant impact on cortical functions, such as cognitive and perceptual abilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: All of the following are types of subcortical dementia, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

 

Option D. 

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare, degenerative, invariably fatal brain disorder that leads to rapid, progressive dementia along with other neurological symptoms. It affects both cortical and subcortical structures but is not classified purely as a subcortical dementia due to its widespread effects across the brain, including significant cortical involvement. CJD is characterized by spongiform changes, neuronal loss, and the presence of prion proteins in the brain, leading to rapid neurodegeneration.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Progressive supranuclear palsy, Option B. Huntington's disease, and Option C. Parkinson's disease dementia are examples of subcortical dementias. These conditions primarily affect the parts of the brain below the cortex, such as the basal ganglia, thalamus, and brainstem, leading to symptoms that differ from those seen in cortical dementias. Subcortical dementias are often characterized by changes in the speed of cognitive processing, attention, and executive function, rather than the aphasia, agnosia, and pronounced memory deficits more typical of cortical dementias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subcortical dementias are characterized by degeneration in the areas of the brain below the cortex, leading to symptoms such as slowed cognitive processing, attention deficits, and executive dysfunction. Examples include progressive supranuclear palsy, Huntington's disease, and Parkinson's disease dementia. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, although it causes dementia and involves subcortical structures, is not classified purely as a subcortical dementia due to its significant cortical involvement and widespread effects across the brain.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 244.

choices.text: Alzheimer's disease has a higher prevalence among females than males.
Insight is typically lost early in the progression of Alzheimer's disease.
The majority of Alzheimer's disease cases are of familial origin.
Late-onset Alzheimer's disease represents the majority of cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Alzheimer's disease is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The majority of Alzheimer's disease cases are of familial origin.

 

Option C.

 

The majority of Alzheimer's disease cases are of familial origin - False. While some cases of Alzheimer's disease are familial, the majority of cases are sporadic, with no clear family history of the disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease has a higher prevalence among females than males - True. This is likely due to a combination of factors, including women's longer life expectancy.

 

Option B. Insight is typically lost early in the progression of Alzheimer's disease - True. Patients often lose awareness of their cognitive decline early in the disease process.

 

Option D. Late-onset Alzheimer's disease represents the majority of cases - True. Late-onset Alzheimer's disease, typically occurring after the age of 65, is the most common form of the disorder.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The majority of Alzheimer's disease (AD) cases are sporadic, meaning they occur at random without a clear familial pattern. Only a small percentage of AD cases, estimated at around 1% to 5%, are truly familial, resulting from genetic mutations in specific genes (such as APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2) that are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. These familial cases often present as early-onset AD, which occurs before the age of 65.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239-240.

Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are composed primarily of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
The presence of the APOE ε4 allele increases the risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease.
The primary mechanism of Alzheimer's disease is the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The primary mechanism of Alzheimer's disease is the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. 

 

The primary mechanism of Alzheimer's disease (AD) involves the accumulation of amyloid-beta plaques and tau protein neurofibrillary tangles in the brain, leading to neuronal dysfunction and death, particularly in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus. The statement about the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is incorrect in the context of Alzheimer's disease; this is a characteristic feature of Parkinson's disease, not AD.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta plaques contributes to neuronal dysfunction: This statement is true. One of the hallmark pathological features of AD is the accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta (Aβ) plaques, which contribute to neuronal dysfunction and death.

 

Option B. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are composed primarily of hyperphosphorylated tau protein: This statement is true. Another hallmark feature of AD is the presence of intracellular neurofibrillary tangles, which are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein. These tangles disrupt the normal function of neurons and contribute to their degeneration.

 

Option C. The presence of the APOE ε4 allele increases the risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease: This statement is true. The APOE ε4 allele is the most significant genetic risk factor for late-onset AD. Individuals carrying one or two copies of the ε4 allele have an increased risk of developing the disease, although having the allele does not guarantee that a person will develop AD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease involves the accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein, leading to neuronal dysfunction and death. The APOE ε4 allele is a genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease.It is associated with loss of cholinergic neurons in nucleus basalis of Meynert.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 240.

Accumulation of beta-amyloid triggers a cascade of events leading to neuronal damage and cognitive decline.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease after a thorough clinical evaluation. The amyloid cascade hypothesis has been proposed as a possible mechanism for the pathogenesis of this disease. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the amyloid cascade hypothesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Accumulation of beta-amyloid triggers a cascade of events leading to neuronal damage and cognitive decline.

 

Option B. 

 

The amyloid cascade hypothesis posits that the accumulation of beta-amyloid (Aβ) peptides in the brain, particularly in the form of extracellular amyloid plaques, is a critical initiating factor in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. According to this hypothesis, the abnormal processing and accumulation of Aβ peptides trigger a series of pathological events, including the formation of neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein), inflammation, oxidative stress, and ultimately, neuronal damage and loss. This cascade of events is believed to contribute to the cognitive decline and other symptoms observed in Alzheimer's disease.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Decreased production of beta-amyloid leads to the formation of neurofibrillary tangles: This statement is incorrect. The amyloid cascade hypothesis focuses on the accumulation of beta-amyloid, not its decrease, as a key event in Alzheimer's disease pathogenesis. The relationship between Aβ accumulation and the formation of neurofibrillary tangles involves complex interactions, but decreased Aβ production is not the proposed mechanism.

 

Option C. The buildup of alpha-synuclein in neurons results in the formation of amyloid plaques: This statement is incorrect in the context of Alzheimer's disease. Alpha-synuclein accumulation is associated with Parkinson's disease and other synucleinopathies, where it forms Lewy bodies, not amyloid plaques. Amyloid plaques in Alzheimer's disease are primarily composed of beta-amyloid peptides.

 

Option D. The hyperphosphorylation of tau protein results in the accumulation of amyloid plaques: This statement is incorrect. While hyperphosphorylated tau protein does form the intracellular neurofibrillary tangles observed in Alzheimer's disease, it is not responsible for the accumulation of amyloid plaques. The amyloid plaques are formed from beta-amyloid peptides, and the relationship between tau pathology and amyloid pathology is an area of ongoing research.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with concerns about his risk of developing early-onset Alzheimer's disease (EOAD). His father was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease at the age of 55, and his paternal grandfather also exhibited memory problems in his early 50s. The patient is worried about the possibility of having a genetic predisposition to EOAD. Which of the following statements is true regarding the genetics of early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene, presenilin-1 (PSEN1) gene, and presenilin-2 (PSEN2) gene are strongly associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B.

Early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease (EOAD), which typically presents before the age of 65, has been linked to mutations in specific genes that lead to the abnormal production of the amyloid-beta protein, a key factor in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. The genes most commonly associated with EOAD are the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene on chromosome 21, the presenilin-1 (PSEN1) gene on chromosome 14, and the presenilin-2 (PSEN2) gene on chromosome 1. Mutations in these genes result in the increased production of the amyloidogenic beta-amyloid 42 peptide, which is prone to aggregation and forms the core of amyloid plaques in the brain, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The majority of early-onset Alzheimer's disease cases are caused by mutations in the APOE gene: This statement is incorrect. While the APOE ε4 allele is a well-known risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (typically presenting after age 65), it is not the cause of the majority of early-onset cases. Early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease is more closely associated with mutations in the APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2 genes.

 

Option C. Genetic testing for early-onset Alzheimer's disease is typically recommended for all individuals with a family history of dementia: This statement is overly broad. Genetic testing may be considered in individuals with a strong family history of early-onset Alzheimer's disease, especially when multiple family members are affected at an early age. However, the decision to undergo genetic testing should involve careful consideration and counseling due to the potential psychological and ethical implications.

 

Option D. The risk of developing early-onset Alzheimer's disease is primarily determined by environmental factors, rather than genetics: This statement is incorrect. While environmental factors can play a role in the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease is strongly influenced by specific genetic mutations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239-240.

Familial Alzheimer's disease accounts for the majority of Alzheimer's cases.
Late-onset Alzheimer's disease is strongly associated with mutations in the APP gene.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with her daughter, concerned about the possibility of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD). The patient's mother was diagnosed with AD at the age of 70, and she recently read about a genetic link to the disease. Which of the following statements is true regarding the genetics of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The presence of an APOE ε4 allele increases the risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option D.

 

The presence of the apolipoprotein E (APOE) ε4 allele is the most significant genetic risk factor identified for late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD), which typically begins after the age of 65. Individuals carrying one ε4 allele have an increased risk of developing AD, and those with two ε4 alleles have an even higher risk. However, it is important to note that not everyone with an APOE ε4 allele will develop Alzheimer's disease, and many people without the allele can still develop the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mutations in the APOE gene are the primary cause of early-onset Alzheimer's disease: This statement is incorrect. Mutations in the APOE gene, specifically the ε4 allele, are associated with an increased risk of late-onset Alzheimer's disease, not early-onset Alzheimer's disease (EOAD). EOAD, which occurs before the age of 65, is more commonly associated with mutations in the APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2 genes.

 

Option B. Familial Alzheimer's disease accounts for the majority of Alzheimer's cases: This statement is incorrect. Familial Alzheimer's disease, which is caused by genetic mutations, accounts for a small percentage of all Alzheimer's cases, estimated at 1% to 5%. The majority of Alzheimer's disease cases are sporadic and have a more complex etiology involving both genetic and environmental factors.

 

Option C. Late-onset Alzheimer's disease is strongly associated with mutations in the APP gene: This statement is incorrect. While mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene are associated with some cases of early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease, they are not commonly associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease. The APP gene mutations lead to the production of abnormal amyloid-beta peptides, which are central to the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease, but these mutations are not typically involved in late-onset cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of the APOE ε4 allele is a significant genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease, increasing the risk of developing the disease but not guaranteeing it. Early-onset Alzheimer's disease, which is less common, is associated with mutations in the APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2 genes. Familial Alzheimer's disease accounts for a small percentage of all cases, with the majority being sporadic.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 240.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is concerned about her risk of developing Alzheimer's disease, as her mother was diagnosed with the condition in her late 70s. She is seeking advice on modifiable risk factors to help lower her risk. Which of the following factors is NOT associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High educational attainment

 

Option C.

 

Higher levels of education have been associated with a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease. This is thought to be because education may help build cognitive reserve, which allows the brain to be more resilient to age-related changes and damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperlipidemia: Elevated cholesterol levels, particularly low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, are associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Type 2 diabetes mellitus: Studies have demonstrated a connection between type 2 diabetes and an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease, possibly due to insulin resistance and inflammation.

 

Option D. Sleep apnea: Sleep apnea and other sleep disturbances have been linked to an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease, potentially due to the disruption of normal sleep patterns and the resulting impact on brain health.

 

Educational objective: 

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239.

choices.text: Antipsychotics are the first-line treatment for BPSD in Alzheimer's disease.
Antipsychotics have no significant side effects in the elderly population with dementia.
Antipsychotics have a black box warning for increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia.
Antipsychotics are contraindicated in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease presents to the clinic with her caregiver, who reports the patient has been experiencing visual hallucinations for the past month. The caregiver is concerned about these symptoms and their impact on the patient's quality of life. Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of antipsychotics in the management of behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antipsychotics have a black box warning for increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia.

 

Option C.

 

Antipsychotics carry a black box warning for increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis. This warning was issued by the FDA due to the increased risk of death associated with the use of these medications in this population.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antipsychotics are not considered first-line treatment for BPSD in Alzheimer's disease. Non-pharmacological interventions are usually tried first, and antipsychotics are reserved for severe cases or when other treatments have failed.

 

Option B. Antipsychotics can have significant side effects in the elderly population with dementia, including an increased risk of falls, sedation, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Although antipsychotics are not contraindicated in Alzheimer's disease, their use should be carefully considered due to the associated risks and potential side effects. They should only be used when other interventions have failed and the potential benefits outweigh the risks. This warning was issued by the FDA due to the increased risk of death associated with the use of these medications in this population. The increased mortality is mainly due to cardiovascular events (e.g., heart failure, sudden death) and infections (e.g., pneumonia). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antipsychotic medications carry a black box warning for an increased risk of mortality when used in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis. Their use in managing behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia should be considered cautiously, only after nonpharmacological interventions have been tried and deemed ineffective, and should be limited to the lowest effective dose for the shortest necessary duration.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter, who is concerned about her mother's progressive memory loss and confusion over the past year. The patient has difficulty recalling recent events and has become increasingly disoriented. Her daughter also reports that her mother has been struggling to manage her daily activities, such as cooking and shopping. The physician decides to perform a cognitive assessment. Which of the following components would be assessed using the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orientation, recall, and language

 

Option C.

 

The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a widely used tool for assessing cognitive function, particularly in the context of evaluating for dementia and other cognitive impairments. The MMSE assesses various cognitive domains, including:

 

  • Orientation: The patient's awareness of time (date, day, month, year) and place (location, city, state).
  • Recall: The ability to remember a short list of words after a brief delay.
  • Language: This includes naming objects, following commands, the ability to write a sentence spontaneously, and copying a complex shape.

 

These components help in evaluating the patient's memory, language skills, and general cognitive functioning, which are commonly affected in dementia syndromes such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hallucinations and delusions are typically assessed during the psychiatric history and mental status examination but are not specifically evaluated by the MMSE. These symptoms can be relevant in dementia, particularly in conditions like Lewy body dementia, but the MMSE focuses on cognitive domains.

 

Option B. Motor coordination and strength are important in a neurological examination but are not assessed by the MMSE, which focuses on cognitive functions rather than motor skills.

 

Option D. Executive function and problem-solving abilities are crucial in cognitive assessments but are not directly measured by the MMSE. The MMSE includes tasks that may indirectly require some executive function, but it is not designed to comprehensively assess this domain. More detailed neuropsychological testing would be needed for a thorough evaluation of executive function and problem-solving skills.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a brief cognitive screening tool that assesses various cognitive domains, including orientation, registration, attention and calculation, recall, and language. It is widely used to assess cognitive impairment in patients with suspected dementia or other neurocognitive disorders. The maximum score on MMSE is 30, a score less than 24 is indicative of cognitive impairment.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 1065.

choices.text: Prominent early memory loss
Fluctuating levels of alertness and attention
Rapid progression to severe dementia within a year

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive cognitive decline, accompanied by visual hallucinations and episodes of motor rigidity. His wife reports that he has also been experiencing sudden falls and episodes of unresponsiveness lasting a few seconds. The neurologist suspects a specific type of dementia. Which of the following characteristics is most consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating levels of alertness and attention

 

Option B.

 

The patient's presentation, including progressive cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, motor rigidity, sudden falls, and episodes of unresponsiveness, is suggestive of Lewy body dementia (LBD). One of the hallmark features of LBD is fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness. Patients with LBD can have periods of relatively normal function interspersed with times of severe confusion and decreased attention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prominent early memory loss is more characteristic of Alzheimer's disease, which typically begins with memory impairment, particularly in short-term memory, before progressing to other cognitive domains.

 

Option C. Slow, shuffling gait is often associated with Parkinson's disease. While Parkinson's disease and LBD share some features, such as motor rigidity due to Lewy bodies, the cognitive symptoms and their pattern, especially the fluctuating cognition, are more indicative of LBD.

 

Option D. Rapid progression to severe dementia within a year is less typical for LBD and might suggest a more aggressive or different neurological condition, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a rare and rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD) is characterized by fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness, visual hallucinations, Parkinsonian motor symptoms, and autonomic dysfunction. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 243.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with his wife, who reports that he has experienced significant behavioral changes over the past year. She describes him as increasingly disinhibited, impulsive, and apathetic. The patient has also been making socially inappropriate remarks and has lost interest in his usual hobbies. His memory and orientation, however, seem to be relatively preserved. The physician is considering a diagnosis of a specific type of dementia. Which of the following types of dementia is most consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontotemporal dementia

 

Option C.

 

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative disorders characterized by progressive atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes of the brain. The clinical presentation of FTD is variable but typically involves prominent changes in personality, behavior, and/or language. The patient's symptoms, such as disinhibition, impulsivity, apathy, and socially inappropriate behavior, are consistent with the behavioral variant of FTD. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease primarily affects memory.

 

Option B. Vascular dementia is characterized by a stepwise decline in cognitive function due to cerebrovascular disease. 

 

Option D. Lewy body dementia typically presents with cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian features. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by degeneration of the frontal and/or temporal lobes, leading to significant changes in behavior, personality, and social conduct, with relative preservation of memory in the early stages. This distinguishes it from Alzheimer's disease, which primarily affects memory, and from other types of dementia, such as vascular dementia and Lewy body dementia, which have different hallmark symptoms.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 243.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive memory loss, difficulty in naming familiar objects, and getting lost while driving to familiar places. Her family history is notable for a father and two siblings who had similar symptoms in their late sixties. Given her family history, which of the following genes is most commonly associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) APP.

 

Option C.

 

The gene most commonly associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene. Mutations in this gene can lead to the production of abnormal amyloid proteins that aggregate and form plaques, a hallmark of Alzheimer's pathology. Early-onset AD, which is defined as AD that occurs before the age of 65, is often associated with genetic mutations, and the APP gene on chromosome 21 is one of the genes implicated.

 

Other genes associated with early-onset familial AD include presenilin 1 (PSEN1) and presenilin 2 (PSEN2). Mutations in these genes affect the processing of APP and lead to the accumulation of amyloid-beta peptides, contributing to the development of AD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. SOD1: The SOD1 gene is associated with familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), not Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. HTT: Mutations in the HTT gene lead to Huntington's disease, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms.

 

Option D. CFTR: The CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, an inherited disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs, digestive system, and other organs in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease is associated with genetic mutations, most commonly in the APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2 genes, which lead to the production and accumulation of amyloid-beta peptides and the development of amyloid plaques, one of the pathologic hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease.

 

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239-240.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his daughter due to increasing forgetfulness over the past year. She is concerned about the possibility of him developing Alzheimer's disease (AD) as his mother had AD. She inquires about risk factors that might predispose him to the disease. Which of the following is a non-modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Age.of 65 years

 

Option C.

 

Age is the most significant non-modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). The likelihood of developing AD increases significantly as individuals grow older, especially after the age of 65. Although having a family history of AD is also a non-modifiable risk factor, it is not one of the options provided. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Hypertension: Hypertension is a modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease. Managing blood pressure through lifestyle changes and medication can help reduce the risk.

 

Option B. Smoking: Smoking is also a modifiable risk factor. Quitting smoking can significantly reduce the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option D. Male gender: While some studies have suggested gender may influence the risk of AD, with women being at a higher risk perhaps due to longer life expectancy, age is still the most significant non-modifiable risk factor among the options provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-modifiable risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease include: 

 

  1. Age- The most important risk factor
  2. Family history of Alzheimer’s disease
  3. Female gender

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is seen in the clinic for a regular health check-up. She expresses concern about her risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD) as her maternal grandmother had the disease. She asks the physician about any controllable factors that could reduce her risk. Which of the following is a modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Physical inactivity

 

Option C.

 

Physical inactivity is considered a modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). Regular physical activity is associated with a reduced risk of cognitive decline and can potentially delay the onset of AD. Exercise can improve cardiovascular health, which is also beneficial for cognitive function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High education levels: Higher levels of education have been associated with a lower risk of AD.

 

Option B. Hypotension: While hypotension (abnormally low blood pressure) can be a health concern, it is not typically listed as a modifiable risk factor for AD. Hypertension (high blood pressure), on the other hand, is a modifiable risk factor for AD.

 

Option D. Gender: Gender is a non-modifiable risk factor. Some studies suggest that women may be at a higher risk of developing AD, potentially related to longer life expectancy and hormonal changes after menopause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modifiable risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease include:

 

  1. Head injury
  2. Physical inactivity
  3. Hypertension
  4. Insulin resistance
  5. Hyperlipidemia
  6. Depression
  7. Obesity
  8. Low education levels
  9. Social isolation

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 239.

choices.text: Multi-infarct areas in the brain.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son due to concerns about his cognitive decline. Over the past 18 months, the patient has become increasingly forgetful, often repeating the same questions several times within an hour. He has difficulty remembering recent events but recalls events from his youth quite vividly. On examination, his orientation to time is impaired, but he correctly identifies place and person. Based on the clinical presentation, which neuropathological finding is most likely to be seen in the above disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibrillary tangles.

 

Option A.

 

The clinical presentation of the 75-year-old man with progressive memory loss, particularly impairment in recent memory with relatively preserved remote memory, and orientation impairment, is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease (AD). One of the hallmark neuropathological findings in Alzheimer's disease is the presence of neurofibrillary tangles. These tangles are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein and are found within the neuronal cytoplasm. They are one of the key features, along with amyloid-beta plaques, observed in the brains of individuals with AD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lewy bodies: These are intracytoplasmic inclusions, primarily composed of alpha-synuclein, found in Lewy body dementia and Parkinson's disease dementia, rather than in classic Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C. Multi-infarct areas in the brain: These are associated with vascular dementia, which occurs due to cumulative damage to the brain through multiple small strokes.

 

Option D. Synuclein aggregates: While synuclein is the primary component of Lewy bodies, its aggregates are not a feature of Alzheimer's disease but are associated with Lewy body dementia and Parkinson's disease dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Neurofibrillary tangles, composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein, are a hallmark neuropathological finding in Alzheimer's disease.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 240.

choices.text: Positron emission tomography (PET) scan showing decreased glucose uptake in the brain.
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score below 24.
Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing decreased beta-amyloid and increased tau proteins.
Postmortem histopathological examination of the brain.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son who expresses concern about her progressive forgetfulness. She often forgets recent conversations and misplaces objects around the house. Although initially alert and oriented, her son reports she has begun to forget the names of close relatives. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. The physician is considering the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Which of the following is the most definitive method for diagnosing AD?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Postmortem histopathological examination of the brain.

 

Option D.

 

The most definitive method for diagnosing Alzheimer's disease (AD) is through postmortem histopathological examination of the brain. This examination can reveal the presence of characteristic neuropathological features of AD, such as amyloid-beta plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, which can definitively confirm the diagnosis. While there are several clinical and imaging methods used to diagnose AD during a patient's lifetime, a definitive diagnosis can only be made by examining the brain tissue after death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Positron emission tomography (PET) scan showing decreased glucose uptake in the brain: While PET scans can show patterns of decreased glucose metabolism in areas of the brain typically affected by AD, this finding is not definitive for AD and can be seen in other types of dementia as well.

 

Option B: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score below 24: The MMSE is a screening tool used to assess cognitive impairment. A score below 24 suggests cognitive impairment, but it is not specific to AD and cannot definitively diagnose the condition.

 

Option C: Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing decreased beta-amyloid and increased tau proteins: Abnormal levels of beta-amyloid and tau proteins in cerebrospinal fluid are indicative of AD, but this finding is not considered definitive for diagnosing AD. It can support the diagnosis when considered alongside clinical symptoms and other diagnostic tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The definitive diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease can only be made through postmortem histopathological examination of the brain, which reveals characteristic neuropathological features such as amyloid-beta plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. While various clinical assessments and imaging studies can strongly suggest AD during a patient's life, they are not definitive.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 240.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive cognitive decline. His daughter reports that he frequently has visual hallucinations and sometimes stares blankly for short periods. Additionally, she mentions episodes of unsteadiness and falls. His medical history is unremarkable. The physician suspects that his symptoms may not be indicative of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Which of the following features is more suggestive of Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) than AD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Visual hallucinations.

 

Option C.

 

The presence of visual hallucinations, particularly detailed and recurrent ones, is more suggestive of Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) than Alzheimer's disease (AD). LBD is characterized by fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness, recurrent visual hallucinations, and features of parkinsonism. The visual hallucinations in LBD are often well-formed and detailed.

 

Other characteristic features of LBD include rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder and sensitivity to neuroleptic medications. The presence of blank staring episodes and unsteadiness leading to falls can also be consistent with LBD, given its overlap with parkinsonian features.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Memory impairment: While memory impairment is a hallmark of AD, it can also occur in LBD. However, in LBD, memory impairment tends to occur later in the disease progression compared to AD.

 

Option B. Fluent aphasia: Fluent aphasia is not typically a feature of LBD. Aphasia, when it occurs in dementia, is more often associated with Alzheimer's disease or other types of dementia.

 

Option D. Apraxia: Apraxia, the inability to perform purposeful movements or use objects correctly, is more commonly associated with Alzheimer's disease, though it can also occur in other types of dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent and detailed visual hallucinations are more suggestive of Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) than Alzheimer's disease. LBD is also characterized by fluctuating cognition, parkinsonian features, and potential complications with neuroleptic medications. While memory impairment and apraxia can be seen in LBD, they are more characteristic of AD, especially in the early stages.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 243.

questions.text: Dr. Aarav, a psychiatrist in Hyderabad, was consulted regarding a 72-year-old man named Kishore. Kishore's daughter, Deepa, reported that over the past year, her father had episodes of visual hallucinations, often describing children playing in the room, though no one was present. She also noted fluctuations in his cognition, with "good days" where he seemed almost his usual self, interspersed with "bad days" where he appeared confused and disoriented. Additionally, Deepa mentioned that Kishore seemed stiffer when walking, often shuffling his feet. Dr. Aarav's examination also revealed a mild resting tremor in Kishore's right hand.  Given the presentation, which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

 

Option C.

 

Kishore's presentation of visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and Parkinsonian features (such as stiffness, shuffling gait, and resting tremor) is characteristic of Lewy body dementia (LBD). Visual hallucinations, particularly well-formed and detailed ones (like seeing children playing in the room), are a hallmark feature of LBD. Fluctuations in cognition, where the patient may have periods of relatively normal cognition interspersed with periods of confusion or decreased alertness, also strongly suggest LBD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease: While Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in older adults, it usually presents with memory impairment as the initial and most prominent symptom. While some neuropsychiatric symptoms like hallucinations can occur, they are not as common as in LBD and do not typically dominate the clinical picture.

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease primarily presents with motor symptoms, including bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Cognitive impairment can develop later in the course of the disease, but it typically does not show the same fluctuating pattern seen in LBD. Moreover, visual hallucinations are less common and tend to appear in the later stages, often in association with medication side effects.

 

Option D. Frontotemporal dementia: This form of dementia usually presents with changes in personality, behaviour, or language. Memory impairment is not a predominant feature, and visual hallucinations are not typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia (Dementia with Lewy Body) is characterized by general symptoms of dementia and additional features which include:

 

  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonian features (hence antipsychotics should be avoided)

 

It is characterized by the presence of inclusion bodies in the neurons (known as Lewy bodies), composed of alpha-synuclein.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 243.
